div.head: Vienna Corpus of Arabic Varieties (VICAV)
div.p: VICAV is an international endeavour aiming at the collection of digital language resources documenting varieties of spoken Arabic. While in principle being open to any type of text, we currently focus on bibliographical data, on so-called language profiles, standardised feature lists and lexical data.

VICAV has a strong methodological component focusing on the development of digital data and tools. A large part of these efforts is concentrated on modelling data and providing documentation for developmental and pedagogical purposes. VICAV is strongly committed to the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI). We provide a detailed documentation of our lexical data.

VICAV has been started as a co-operation between the Department of Oriental Studies of the University of Vienna and the Austrian Centre for Digital Humanities of the Austrian Academy of Sciences (ACDH-OeAW). The institutional frame of the project is defined by a repository for digital research data, a University and a national Academy, all of which is meant to ensure long-term availability of both data and the web-interface.

div.head: Linguistics
div.p: The VICAV Research Environment has been designed as a tool for the presentation of digital material concerning Arabic dialectology. It was intended as a means to promote the efficient exchange of ideas and experiences in an active international community.

VICAV serves as an interface between areal and corpus linguistics. The aim is to gather varying digital language resources for a number of different localities. The description of the different varieties hinges on a particular type of text which we call ’language profiles’, concise and standardised ‘form sheets’ that display uniformly arranged information on research history, available literature, salient grammatical features etc. The website will also make accessible bibliographies, dictionaries, glossaries, and different types of transcribed texts.

The project proceeds from two basic assumptions: In Arabic dialectology, information on new findings and current developments is mainly exchanged at international conferences and in scientific journals. Due to a steadily increasing number of projects which produce digital data too there is an increasing need to make these data quickly available to others in the field. There already exist a couple of individual webpages which - due to the lack of resources - often do not match professional standards. There is a big gap between the linguistics communities and Arabic Studies in general and Arabic dialectology in particular. Linguistic studies in Arabic dialects have widely ignored the works of traditional, i.e. philologically based, dialectology and vice versa. We are convinced that VICAV has the potential to help to bridge this gap to the benefit of both disciplines.

div.head: Data
div.p: All entries in the dictionaries which are not further indicated are taken from data provided by the collaborator(s) cited on the front page of each dictionary. Data extracted from other published sources is indicated as such and includes the respective reference.

div.head: Transcription
div.p: The transcription follows a system which is widely accepted in Arabic studies and also used in reference works such as the Encyclopedia of Arabic Language and Linguistics (Leiden: Brill, 2006-2009).
Following a widespread convention in Arabic dialectology, the data is presented in in a broad phonological transcription that does not indicate allophones.

div.head: Arabic roots
div.p: In order to facilitate cross-dialectal comparative search all word roots are have to be taken as being strictly etymological, i.e. they reflect the corresponding roots of Standard Arabic wherever possible. The source of reference is the Dictionary of Modern Written Arabic by Hans Wehr (English version edited by J. Milton Cowell, Wiesbaden: Harrassowitz, 1979). For words which have entered Arabic from other languages a (in many hypothetical) root consisting of the mere consonantal structure of the word in question is given.

div.head: Part-of-speech
div.p: As for verbs a subcategory indicating the so-called verbal form is provided (using the traditional order labelled by Roman numerals from I to X, in case of quadriliteral roots Iq and IIq).

In many cases a clear distinction between adjective and active or passive participle is not possible. If a given lemma is mainly used in an adjectival sense it is labelled as such but with an additional category that indicates the word is morphologically seen a participle.
The gender of Arabic nouns is not noted unless it is contradictory to the rules of Arabic morphology (which is particularly the case with unmarked feminine nouns).

div.head: Features (Explanation)
div.p: The linguistic features consist in lists of sentence pairs in English and Arabic that are meant to exemplify selected salient linguistic features of the particular varieties. The list is regarded as work in progress and serves as a basis for discussion. The system is designed in an extensible manner, open for any amendments, refinements and enhancements. Let us know what you think about it, what you would add.
Nomenclature should reflect the common practice in the community and follow linguistically acknowledged standards. It is planned to enter the chosen denominations as a draft in the ISOCat list.

The list contains a number of repeated examples. We have tried to avoid phenomena that are too elusive or difficult to ascertain such as e.g. secondary emphasis. The focus has been put on morphology and lexis.
The lists have also been put together with a didactic purpose in mind. They should allow students of Arabic dialectology to quickly get a first impression of particular dialects.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: The TUNICO dictionary was not only built on data from the corpus of spoken language that was compiled in the same project, but also on a range of additional sources: data elicited from complementary interviews with young Tunisians and lexical material taken from various published historical sources dating from the middle of the 20th century and earlier. The most important of these is Hans-Rudolf Singer’s monumental grammar (1984; almost 800 pages) of the Medina of Tunis. Singer’s data was systematically evaluated and integrated into the dictionary, all the material being indicated by reference to the book. Additionally, other resources including (Nicolas 1911, Marçais/Guîga 1958-61, Quéméneur 1962, Abdellatif 2010) were also consulted in order to verify and to complete the contemporary data. The diachronic dimension will help to better understand processes in the development of the lexicon (for more details see Moerth, Prochazka, & Dallaji 2014).

The first layer of lexical data to be incorporated into the digital lexicographical system was extracted from Veronika Ritt-Benmimoun’s textbook titled Skriptum zu den Lehrveranstaltungen Tunesisch-Arabisch Kurs A und B (Vienna, 2012/13). This data is referenced in the dictionary as Ritt-Benmimoun 2014.

Please keep in mind that the dictionary will remain work-in-progress. We do not claim any degree of completeness, neither with respect to lemmas nor with respect to data relevant to the entries’ microstructure. This holds particularly true for etymologies and usage labels indicating regimen of verbs.

The project was embedded in the activities of the two large-scale pan-European research infrastructure consortia in the humanities, CLARIN (Common Language Resources and Technology Infrastructure) and DARIAH (Digital Research Infrastructure for the Arts and Humanities) (Budin, Moerth, & Durco 2013).

div.head: Dictionary Encoding
div.p: Dictionaries are highly complex knowledge stores on the modelling of which lots of efforts have been spent since we have started to compile digital dicitionaries. The VICAV project has been dedicated to the use of the guidelines of the Text Encoding Inititative in all of its dictionaries.

The team have documented their work in a document which exemplifies the most important structures contained in these dictionaries. The
VICAV Dictionary Encoding Guidelines are meant to allow researchers in similar projects to draw on the experiences of our work.

div.head: Viennese Lexicographic Editor (VLR)
div.p: VLE is a fairly new piece of software that first came into existence as a by-product of an entirely different development activity: the creation of an interactive online learning system for university students. Thus, it was first used in a collaborative glossary editing project carried out as part of university language courses at the University of Vienna. As the tool proved to be flexible and adaptable enough, it was also put to work in other projects. The interface is built around an XML editor. The communication between the dictionary client and the server has been implemented as a RESTful web service.

The interface is built around an XML editor that allows to process standard-based lexicographic and terminological data, basically any XML-based format such as LMF, TBX, RDF, or TEI can be handled. The program provides a number of useful functions to automate editing procedures. It can check the structural integrity (well-formedness) of input on the fly. Technologically, it draws not only on the XML core specification but also on several cognate technologies. XSLT and XPath play an important role both for visualizing and modifying existing datasets. Lexicographers can insert elements on the basis of predefined XML Schemas. Most of the functions can be applied both to single and multiple lemmas. One of the most recent improvements is a versioning system and an improved working mode that allows lexicographers to work on the XML data without actually seeing the tags. Furthermore, the editor also has a configurable interface enabling lexicographers to access external corpora and to integrate example sentences from them into dictionary entries. The communication between the dictionary client and the server has been implemented as a RESTful web service.

div.head: Vocabularies on the Smartphone
div.p: One way to learn vocabularies is to use flashcards. The ubiquitous smartphones make it possible to carry around thousands of vocabulary cards in your pocket. Before we started to cary around a computer in our pockets, the most common way to carry them around as paper flashcards. The problem with this approach is that they can take up quite some space if you want to repeat cards from say 20 units of some language course at least now and then. Now we only have to decide on what software to use.

div.head: Available Programs
div.p: There are several programs that help you repeat vocabularies on the smartphone. To get an overview of available tools have a look at Wikipedia. We provide some data for ANKI and Flashcards Deluxe.

div.head: ANKI
div.p: ... is a spaced repetition flashcard program. "Anki" is Japanese for memorization. You can find details about the program on Wikipedia.
You can download the program from the AnkiWeb webiste. If you want to synch your learning progress over the internet you might consider registering with ankiweb.

As a quick start we provide a template "deck" with all the required settings called Empty 4 by 4. By importing this template into Anki you get

div.head: Arabic Research Tools
div.p: The intention of this section of VICAV is to bring together the most important tools needed by digitally working linguists in the field of Arabic studies. In compiling this list, we have proceded from a very wide understanding of the term "tool" considering a varied range of digital applications that are typically used in doing linguistic research. This comprises all relevant digital language resources as well as pertaining documentation, standards and best practices.

While there have not been around many NLP tools to process Arabic language data in the past, the situation has definitely changed in recent years. The following list is a first attempt to create a list of tools used by the VICAV crew and other relevant projects.
A very interesting overview of digital Arabic language ressources is Wajdi Zaghouani's Critical Survey of the Freely Available Arabic Corpora.

We have put together some reference material which is not meant to be exhaustive. The focus is on freely available resources. We do not list details from the many resources available through the Linguistic Data Consortium (LDC) and the European Language Resource Association (ELRA). The material has been organised in the following groups:
Corpora (Spoken Varieties)
Corpora (Modern Written Language)
Corpora (Historical Varieties)
Special Corpora
Dictionaries
Language Processing Tools
Other Websites & Projects

div.head: Corpora (Spoken Varieties)
div.p: The number of digitally encoded Arabic language corpora has been on the rise in recent years. The following list is an attempt at listing those that are relevant to linguistic research and is by no means meant to be exhaustive. Please let us know about missing items.

div.head: CorpAfroAs
div.p: CorpAfroAs was an integrated pilot project that also produced Arabic data. On the project web site, you can find extensive information on how to build corpora of spoken language. The data is available.

div.head: CORVAM Speech corpus of Maghrebi varieties
div.p: This very recent development is a tool for the study of Arabic and Berber varieties in the Maghreb in terms of teaching and research and for the preservation of language and culture in the Maghreb. The corpus is a result of the research team nhəḍṛu. Dialectología y sociolingüística del Magreb, and has been conducted at the University of Zaragoza with the participation of members from other universities and research institutes both from Spain and abroad. The project has been been developed under the lead of Ángeles Vicente and the website is being hosted by the University of Zaragoza.

div.head: TUNICO
div.p: The TUNICO Corpus was created as part of the project Linguistic dynamics in the Greater Tunis Area: a corpus-based approach which ran from August 2013 until July 2016. TUNICO grew as a satellite project out of the VICAV project.

div.head: Tunisian Arabic Corpus
div.p: This is a comparatively large corpus of Tunisian Arabic mainly collected from the Internet. The corpus has a very nice web interface.

div.head: Corpus of Moroccan Arabic Writers of Short Stories and Literary Reviews
div.p: Information on this corpus can be found here.

div.head: In their own voices, in their own words: A sociolinguistically-informed corpus of Nigerian Arabic
div.p: This corpus which is hosted by the university of Bayreuth has been created by Jonathan Owens who has also published extensively about Nigerian Arabic.

div.head: Gumar Corpus
div.p: The Gulf Arabic Corpus (Gumar) was created as part of the Computational Approaches to Modeling Languages CAMeL lab in New York University Abu Dhabi NYUAD. The corpus contains a unique genre of written material, anonymous publicly published long conversational novels. A a huge collection of these novels was found online in one place. 1,200 MS Word documents were automatically downloaded.

div.head: Arabic Dialects Dataset
div.p: This collection is one of several corpora being provided by Mahmoud El-Haj (Lancaster Univesity). It consists in transcriptions of Arabic script of Gulf, Egypt, Levantine and Tunisian Arabic dialects in addition to MSA.

div.head: Arabic Speech Corpus
div.p: The Arabic Speech Corpus was developed by Nawar Halabi at the University of Southampton. It was recorded in south Levantine Arabic (Damascian accent) using a professional studio. Synthesized speech as an output using this corpus has produced a high quality, natural voice. It is released here under a non-commercial creative commons license.

div.head: Corpora (Modern Written Language)
div.p: The number of corpora of Modern Standard Arabic have been on the rise over the past two decades. Still, the number of readily available material is rather limited.

div.head: KALIMAT Multipurpose Arabic Corpus
div.p: KALIMAT is an Arabic natural language resource that consists of Arabic articles collected from the Omani newspaper Alwatan. It was prepared by Mahmoud El-Haj (Lancaster University). Articles in the collection fall into six categories: culture, economy, local-news, international-news, religion, and sports. KALIMAT is freely available via sourceforge.net.

div.head: International Corpus of Arabic (ICA)
div.p: The International Corpus of Arabic (ICA) is an ambitious attempt to build a representative corpus of the Arabic language as it is used all over the Arab world, with the aim of supporting research on such language. The ICA is planned to contain 100 million words. Once finished, the analyzed version will be the first analyzed Arabic corpus available as a linguistic resource for researchers. It is also the first systematic investigation of national varieties within the Arabic speaking community, this should prove very useful for linguists who believe that their theories and descriptions of language should be based on real, rather than contrived, data."

div.head: arabiCorpus
div.p: This corpus is a sizeable corpus (173,600,000 words) containing texts in five main categories or genres: Newspapers, Modern Literature, Nonfiction, Egyptian Colloquial, and Premodern. It has been maintained by Dil Parkinson, professor of Arabic and allows users to find larger structures and grammatical patterns through frequency analysis, regular expression searching, and other interface features.

div.head: Wortschatz Universität Leipzig
div.p: This website offers access to large amounts of data crawled form the Internet. There is also Arabic data available. The data is unstructured, search results come with little metadata. However, the results are enriched with cooccurrences which makes it a verz interesting tool both for learners and lexicographers.

div.head: King Abdulaziz City for Science and Technology (KACST) Arabic corpus
div.p: The KACST Arabic corpus is claimed to be a carefully sampled corpus the contents of which are classified based on time, region, medium, domain and topic. It comprises more than 700 million words from the pre-Islamic era to the present day (a period covering more than 1,500 years). However, most of the data belongs into the recent past which is why it is listed under MSA. It can be explored on the Internet using a variety of tools.

div.head: Sketch Engine Corpora
div.p:
Sketch Engine is a corpus manager and text analysis software that has been developed by Lexical Computing Limited since 2003. It allows to analyse large amounts of textual data and is primarily used by lexicographers and linguists. Sketch Engine also provides corpora in currently 90+ languages. There are several
Arabic corpora available which come as part of the regular payable subscription.

div.head: WebCorp Live
div.p: The website offers a suite of tools which allows direct access to the World Wide Web as a corpus.

div.head: Leeds Arabic Corpora
div.p: Serge Sharoff's interface allows to search several corpora. The list contains an Arabic Internet corpus, Al-Hayat News corpus (1999-2001), an Arabic Wikipedia from 2008, a Computer Science corpus and others.

div.head: Arabic Concordancer
div.p: AC is an interface to a corpus published by the International Islamic University of Malaysia. The corpus itself is not available. On the website it says that it contains 14 million Arabic words taken from various academic resources such as theses, journal articles, conferences papers etc.

div.head: Arabic Learner Corpus (ALC)
div.p: The ALC aims to provide a collection of written and spoken materials produced by learners of Arabic in Saudi Arabia.

div.head: Sharing Ancient Wisdoms (SAWS)
div.p: The SAWS Dynamic Library contains five main groups of texts. Elvira Wakelnig and colleagues in Vienna have made available two collections, Gnomological Material in Arabic and in Arabic-Spanish transmission, and Arabic Philosophical Compendia and Excerpts of Arabic and Latin Philosophical Texts; these include, among others, transcriptions of two abridgements of the Ṣiwān al-ḥikma, Ps.-ʿĀmirī’s Kitāb al-Saʿāda, the first editions of three unpublished Arabic compilations of philosophical material, together with further excerpts from relevant texts, from Greek sources and from the Spanish Bocados di Oro whch drew on this tradition. Apophthegmata et gnomae secundum alphabetum comprises the first full edition of an important tradition of Greek gnomologia, arranged in alphabetical order, and edited from 16 manuscripts by Denis Searby and colleagues in Uppsala. A collection of Greek florilegia: Pinakes, prepared by Roueché and Searby, presents the tables of contents from three previously published Greek gnomologia, to give a further sense of the concerns characteristic of such assemblages. Kekaumenos, Consilia et Narrationes, is a new edition, by Charlotte Roueché, of an 11th century Greek text which is profoundly influenced by the tradtion of gnomologia. See a map of the manuscripts which we are publishing.

div.head: A Digital Corpus for Graeco-Arabic Studies
div.p: This digital corpus assembles a wide range of Greek texts and their Arabic counterparts. It also includes a number of Arabic commentaries and important secondary sources. The texts in the corpus can be consulted individually or side by side with their translation. The majority of texts can also be downloaded for further analysis.

div.head: The Quranic Arabic Corpus
div.p: This corpus is an annotated linguistic resource which shows the Arabic grammar, syntax and morphology for each word in the text of the Quran. The corpus provides three levels of analysis: morphological annotation, a syntactic treebank and a semantic ontology. The linguistic structure of verses is represented using dependency graphs. The corpus is available under the GNU public license.

div.head: Digital Archive for the Study of pre-Islamic Arabian Inscriptions (DASI)
div.p: DASI seeks to gather all known pre-Islamic Arabian epigraphic material into a comprehensive online database, with the aim to make available to specialists and to the broader public a wide array of documents often underestimated because of their difficulty of access.

By means of a digitization process through a hybrid data entry/xml system developed by the Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa according to international encoding standards, DASI gives access at present to more than 7,000 Ancient South Arabian inscriptions recorded by the University of Pisa team under the direction of Alessandra Avanzini. Thanks to the fruitful collaboration with other two major European centres for the study of the epigraphic documentation of the Arabian Peninsula, also sections of the two corpora of Ancient North Arabian inscriptions (supervision by Michael C.A. Macdonald, University of Oxford) and Aramaic inscriptions (supervision by Laila Nehmé, UMR 8167, CNRS-Paris) are being prepared for consultation.

div.head: The Arabic Papyrology Database (APD)
div.p: APD is a tool enabling you to access the editions of Arabic documents written on different material such as papyrus, parchment or paper. Those productive editions are an often unraised treasure for almost every aspect of Islamic history up to the 16th c. A.D.

div.head: Analytical Database of Arabic Poetry
div.p: The project aims at documenting the transmission of early Arabic poetry. The database represents a contribution to European research on the Arabic language and the Arabic philological heritage, which so far lacks even such fundamental tools as an etymological dictionary of the Arabic language or a complete dictionary of Classical Arabic.

div.head: The Princeton Geniza Project
div.p: The Princeton Geniza Project is a searchable database of documentary Geniza texts. The corpus currently consists of 4,320 transcriptions in Judaeo-Arabic, Hebrew, Aramaic and Arabic.

div.head: Perseus Digital Library
div.p: The Perseus Digital Library, the central hub for digital language ressources in the Latin and Ancient Greek languages, also contains historical Arabic language documents.

div.head: Islamic Law Materialized
div.p: This corpus contains primary sources for Islamic law and legal practice in pre-modern Muslim societies. The online presentation is the first ever collection of scattered editions of legal documents from the 2nd/8th to the 9th/15th century, often with improved readings compared to earlier print versions. Documents are presented with the Arabic text in modern spelling and with full bibliographical data.

div.head: Thesaurus d'épigraphie islamique
div.p: This website is accessible to registered users only.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: Over the past few years, the number of online Arabic dictionaries has soared rapidly. Many websites offering online access to dictionaries pursue commercial interests capitalising on easily available data in order to create revenues through commercials. Many of these are of little use to serious research. Addresses often change which makes it impossible to reference them in a persistent manner, the provenance of data is in many cases not clear and the quality of information—at best—dubious. The following list only contains a chosen few which have been arpound for some time already and/or have grown out of research projects.

div.head: Verbes de l’arabe égyptien: Dictionnaire contextuel raisonné des verbes du dialecte égyptien (parler du Caire)
div.p: This specialised dictionary has been online since 2012.

div.head: Mawrid Reader: Arabic dictionary interface
div.p: This website offers reading access to a number of Arabic dictionaries.

div.head: Glossarium Græco-Arabicum: A lexicon of the mediæval Arabic translations from the Greek
div.p: The website offers access to the files of a lexical project having studied the lexicon of mediæval Arabic translations from the Greek.

div.head: Lughatuna: The Living Arabic Project
div.p: This website offers a dictionary interface. It appears to be the work of an enthusiastic hobby lexicographer.

div.head: Language Processing Tools
div.p: Meanwhile, there exist numerous tools for processing Arabic language data. However, tools that are readily usable and freely available are still scarce.

div.head: Morphological Analyzers
div.p: Morphlogial processors or taggers assign labels to tokens (wordforms). They can isolate stems, identify word classes (POS=part of speech) or add other morpho-syntactic data to the wordforms.

div.head: Buckwalter Arabic morphological analyzer
div.p: This has definitely been the most widely applied tool in the field used by at least two generations of computational linguists.

div.head: JAVA Arabic Stemmer
div.p: This programm, also known as Khoja Arabic Stemmer and Tagger, was written in JAVA and is available from the sourceforge code repository.

div.head: ADAM: Analyzer for Dialectal Arabic Morphology
div.p: ADAM is a tool that builds on Buckwalter's analyzer.

div.head: Parsers
div.p: A parser is a tool that performs an automatic analysis of the syntactic structure of digital texts.

div.head: The Stanford Parser
div.p: It is licensed under a GNU General Public License and comes with extensive support for Arabic.

div.head: Introduction to Arabic Natural Language Processing (Synthesis Lectures on Human Language Technologies)
div.p: To our knowldge, this book by Nizar Y. Habash (Morgan and Claypool 2010) is the only monography exclusivly dealing with Arabic NLP. It also comprises a bibliography of relevant other pulications which meanwhile has been outdated by many more publications in the field.

div.head: المدونات اللغوية ودورها في معالجة النصوص العربية
div.p: "Corpora and their Role in Processing Arabic Texts" by Ayman Eddakrouri was published in 2018 and deals with a wide range of digital language ressources.

div.head: Database of Arabic Dialects (ضاد)
div.p: This database collects published and unpublished data on Arabic dialects in a searchable electronic format. The frontend allows to formulate quite complex queries. There is also a YouTube presentation of the functionalities of this database.

div.head: Arabic Concordance Sampler
div.p: This is a website that brings together a lot of information concerning digital language resources for teaching and research.

div.head: KITAB
div.p: KITAB provides a digital tool-box and a forum for discussions about Arabic texts. We wish to empower users to explore Arabic texts in completely new ways and to expand the frontiers of knowledge about one of the world’s largest and most complex textual traditions.

div.head: Wellcome Arabic Manuscripts Online
div.p: The Arabic manuscripts collection of the Wellcome Library (London) comprises around 1000 manuscript books and fragments relating to the history of medicine. For the first time this website enables a substantial proportion of this collection to be consulted online via high-quality digital images of entire manuscripts and associated rich metadata.

div.head: Dual Approach
div.p: The VICAV website is designed in a manner supposed to allow users to investigate the available ressources through various methods. The basic access mode is to launch a query by clicking on the symbols on the map.

There are two distinct symbols: arrows and circles. The arrows indicate particular locations (towns, parts of towns, villages), the circles are used for regions which can but do not necessarily correlate with countries.
Some queries can be triggered through clicking on a menu item or by formulating explicit queries.

div.head: Open Source & Open Access
div.p: VICAV is all about sharing. You can reuse both the code and the data used on this website under . We strongly believe that sharing digital tools and data is an efficient way to accelerate knowledge transfer in the field and to make many research processes more efficient.
The code for the website can be found on GitHub.
All the texts are made available through the ARCHE repository and are available under CC BY-SA 4.0.

div.head: Digital Humaniteis & Text Technology
div.p: VICAV has been designed from the very beginning as a project bridging the gap between traditional concepts in the humanities and innovative technological approaches. We have been building our work on the paradigms of the digital humanity community: digital tools and data, collaborative settings and open science are the basis of our work.

By text technology we understand a broad spectrum of methods and tools being applied to a wide range of applications beyond the narrower field of computational linguistics with its focus on large corpora and mainly statistical approaches.

div.head: Contributing
div.p: VICAV is a group effort. Your support is highly welcome. Write a profile, write a sample text, share your lexical data or help us in improving the bibliography.

We highly value our cooperators and do our best to credit them. The author of a text is always mentioned in all the profiles, the sample texts, feature lists and dictionary entries. Unfortunately, we did not find a way to preserve who did what in ZOTERO while transfering data not the VICAV database. However, your name will still be mentioned in the list of contributors.

div.head: Design Principles
div.p: Displaying complexly structured scholarly contents on screens has always been a design challenge. What has made the situation even more complicated is that these days web applications are supposed to run on any kind of device. VICAV is basically built on responsive technology. However, the website has not been optimised for use on smaller mobile devices yet.

Research environments have to work on the Internet these days, which means they need to be implemented as web interfaces that run in browsers. By doing this, one forgoes the powerful possibilities of the windows based systems, on the other side you attaina higher degree of systemic interoperability, reusability and will definitely be able to address a much larger audience.

One drawback of the browser approach has been, that it is usually not possible to have several tabs next to each other which hampers any processes aiming at comparing texts. Whenever you want to juxtapose data one has to find other approaches. One possibility to create a flexible solution to the issue of structuring data on a single surface has been "panelification", visualising data in smaller units that actually emulate forms or windows. We have been experimenting with several approaches. In previous versions of VICAV, the panels were freely movable on the screen which gave users a lot of flexibility to arrange the materials they were interested in on the screen. However, experience has shown that the screen tends to get cluttered easily.

The current approach strikes a balance between a structure where the user has full control over the psoition and size of panels and a static approach where particualr types of text have a fixed position on the screen. Most data on the VICAV website is now displayed in collapsible panels which have a fixed size and fixed positions. Users can open and close these panels, has some control over their size and has full control over the order in whcih he accesses particular contens. Like this, it is still possible to juxtapose particular items and compare them by open them in the right order.

'Overcrowding' of the screen is avoided by a simple mechanisms that collapses panels when there are more than three panels open. The collapsed panels still remain on the screen and can be reopened at any time. Panels which trigger queries stay open as long as they serve this purpose.

You can open and close any of these panels making use of the controls on the purple bar on the left side. The X in the circle closes the panel completely. The arrow-dash sign allows to open and close it.
The relativley small display area of the panels can be enlarged by clicking on "Expand Panels over Map".
To make space for new queries you can "Close All Panels".
